arm_group.description: Stroke survivors are trained to measure and enter BP into an online health management tool

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a feasibility study of using health-IT to promote self-management of risk factors in
      stroke survivors.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Acute Stroke Survivors and their caregivers

          -  English speaking

          -  History of hypertension

        Exclusion Criteria:

        -Cannot use the health-IT system

clinical_study.official_title: Promoting Self-Management in Stroke Survivors Using Health IT

primary_outcome.description: The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) have cited the JNC-7 in their guidelines to define normal blood pressure as < 120/80. We will use these guidelines and examine rates (percentage of subjects) of blood pressure control in intervention vs. usual care group.
primary_outcome.measure: Rate of blood pressure control into guideline recommended ranges

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Percent of subjects who have discontinued one or more of the blood pressure medications on their own (i.e. without medical direction) in the intervention vs. usual care group.

Ease of online health management tool use will be operationalized as the percent of subjects in the intervention group who measure their BP and enter it online at least 75% of the study period, 50% of the study period and those with 25% or less of the study period.

clinical_study.source: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

collaborator.agency: Berman Center for Outcomes and Clinical Research

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Health Services Research
